sentences: He performed with many bands early in his career; then in the summer of 1995, he joined the group The Pale Ones, which would later change their name to Slipknot.
Jordison played in Slipknot since their formation until his departure from the band in December 2013.
Of Slipknot's nine-member lineup, which lasted from 1999–2010, Joey was the third to join the band.
He was the drummer and founder of Scar the Martyr, which formed in 2013 and disbanded in 2016.
He was the drummer and founder of Scar the Martyr, which formed in 2013 and disbanded in 2016.
Jordison was born in Des Moines, Iowa, on April 26, 1975, to Steve and Jackie Jordison.
After a multitude of lineup changes—including Craig Jones and Josh Brainard, who would reappear in Slipknot—the band released two demos in 1993:
In March 1994, after a recommendation from his new friend, he got a job at a Sinclair garage in Urbandale.
In early 1995, Modifidious disbanded because of a shift in interest from thrash metal to death metal in America.
During the forming period of Slipknot, Paul recruited Joey to join a punk band called the Have Nots in the Spring of 1996.

Joey would leave the Have Nots in February 1997 to "focus on Slipknot" but instead reformed the Rejects, which would play Des Moines up until Slipknot left to record Slipknot's self-titled album, which Paul played in after the Have Nots broke up.
On November 28, 1995, Mark Anthony Cadavos approached Jordison while he was working, offering him a position in a new project called The Pale Ones.
Joey produced one album with Slipknot: 2005 live album 9.0: Live.
In August 2008, Jordison broke his ankle and Slipknot had to cancel some of its English tour dates.
On August 22, 2009, Jordison was taken to the emergency room for a burst appendix, less than an hour before he was to take the stage for Auburn, Washington's KISW Pain in the Grass concert.
On December 12, 2013, Slipknot announced through their official website that Jordison had left the band, citing personal reasons for his departure.

After years of both sides being silent and evasive as to the reasons for his leaving the band, Jordison revealed in June 2016 that he suffered from transverse myelitis, a neurological disease that cost him the ability to play the drums toward the end of his time with Slipknot.
While touring Ozzfest in 2001 to support Slipknot's studio album Iowa, Jordison met Tripp Eisen, then of Static-X; the two discussed forming a side project.
In 2002, Jordison revived his band The Rejects, renaming them the Murderdolls.
Murderdolls signed with Roadrunner Records and released an EP entitled Right to Remain Violent in 2002.
The band returned in August 2002 with their debut album Beyond the Valley of the Murderdolls.
On October 30, 2002, the Murderdolls made an appearance on an episode of Dawson's Creek entitled "Living Dead Girl".
The band reunited in 2010 with only Jordison and Wednesday 13 remaining from the original line-up.
The band released their second studio album Women & Children Last on August 31, 2010.
The tour finished on April 24, 2011.
This was considered to be the band's last outing as Wednesday 13 confirmed the band's split in an interview in March 2013.
In April 2013 details emerged of a new band featuring Jordison, Jed Simon and Kris Norris.
On May 5, 2016, Jordison announced that the project had been disbanded.
On May 5, 2016, Jordison announced in an interview on Sirius XM that he had launched a new band called Vimic.
In an interview with Wall of Sound in 2018, Jordison explained Vimic was "still 100% active".
On May 20, 2016, Jordison announced a new extreme metal band Sinsaenum, dual fronted by vocalist Attila Csihar (of Mayhem and Sunn O)))) along with keyboardist Sean Zitarsky ( of Chimaira and Dååth).
The second album, called Repulsion for Humanity, was released on August 10, 2018.
In 2001, Jordison worked on a remix of "The Fight Song" by Marilyn Manson.
In 2004, Jordison appeared on OTEP's album House of Secrets, drumming on six tracks for the album.
In 2008, Jordison appeared on Puscifer's album "V" is for Viagra.
In 2010, Jordison recorded four additional songs with Rob Zombie for the re-release of his latest album Hellbilly Deluxe 2.
While preparing for the Download Festival in 2004, Metallica drummer Lars Ulrich was hospitalized for an unknown illness.
In late 2004, Jordison performed with Satyricon on their tour of the United States when drummer Frost was refused entry into the country.
In 2006, Jordison joined Ministry for their "MasterBaTour 2006", which consisted of sixty dates across the United States and Canada.
Korn recruited Jordison in 2007 to join them on tour when drummer David Silveria went on hiatus from the band.
In August 2004, Jordison became involved in Roadrunner United, a celebration of Roadrunner Records' 25th anniversary.
In 2007, 3 Inches of Blood recruited Jordison to produce their album Fire Up the Blades.

In September 2013 Jordison was named the world's greatest metal drummer by readers of Loudwire.
In 2016 Jordison was honored with The Golden God Award at the Metal Hammer Golden Gods Awards.
